explanation:
For MISRA rule checking that a function parameter is not modified, the next analyzer must know whether any referenced symbols could legally or effectively alter the parameter variables (idtype, name, token) inside this function. Provide the following: 

- Prototypes for each callee (OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch, OS_ObjectIdFindNextFree, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel, OS_NotifyEvent, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew): to see the exact parameter types (e.g. whether any take a pointer-to-pointer or take the address of a parameter) and whether any are actually function-like macros. If a callee accepts a pointer-to-(parameter-type) or a pointer-to-pointer, that could indicate the caller might be passing &token (which would allow modification of the parameter variable); the prototypes also show const qualifiers. Knowing whether a name is a macro vs a real function is necessary because a macro could expand into code that reassigns a parameter variable by name.

- OS_object_token_t (type/struct definition): to confirm what token points to (is it an opaque struct, an integer typedef, etc.). If token is itself a typedef to a pointer type, that affects whether operations in this function might be reassigning the actual parameter rather than the pointee.

- osal_objtype_t (type/enum definition): to confirm whether idtype is a plain value type or a typedef requiring special handling (and whether it is const-qualified anywhere). This helps determine if idtype could be modified and how it is passed to callees.

- OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND, OS_ERR_NAME_TAKEN, OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (macros/constants): to check whether any of these are implemented as expressions or macros that could have side effects (unusual but possible) or expand into code that references parameter names.

- OS_SharedGlobalVars and OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER (declaration/constant): to confirm GlobalState access is a plain read and that the shutdown check does not involve any macro that could reassign parameters.

Collecting these symbols lets the analyzer determine definitively whether the function body or any expanded macros/callees could reassign the parameter variables (idtype, name, token) — the only prohibited action under the MISRA rule — as opposed to modifying the objects they point to (which is permitted).
